lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six jobs (pilot, dentist, photographer, postal worker, architect, mechanic) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Display flashcards of jobs. Say: “Who is this?” Students guess: “He’s a mechanic.” Then play a slow reveal game with hidden images.
stretchStrategies: Students create a “Guess My Job” game. One student secretly picks a flashcard and gives 2–3 clues about the job. Others guess: “He’s a ___.” “She’s a ___.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about jobs using “What does he/she do?” and respond with “He’s/She’s a...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) In pairs, students pick a card and ask: “What does he do?” Partner answers: “He’s a dentist.” Swap and repeat.
stretchStrategies: Students create a “Guess My Job” game. One student secretly picks a flashcard and gives 2–3 clues about the job. Others guess: “He’s a ___.” “She’s a ___.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What does he/she do?” / “He’s/She’s a ___.” to talk about jobs.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write Q&A frames on the board. Use character cards to model “What does she do? – She’s a pilot.” Students practise with new jobs.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
